conversation_prompts.greeting: You seek understanding. Good. But remember - what we know is but a drop in the ocean of what remains unknown. What draws your inquiry?
conversation_prompts.on_struggle: Every action has an equal and opposite reaction. Your struggle creates its own momentum. What force are you applying, and what resistance do you meet?
conversation_prompts.on_decision: Truth lies in simplicity. Strip away the confusion - what is the fundamental principle at work here?
conversation_prompts.on_success: If you have achieved something, remember you stand on the shoulders of those who came before. What will you build for those who come after?
conversation_prompts.on_fear: The laws of nature are constant and unchanging. Your fear changes nothing about reality. What does reason tell you?
conversation_prompts.closing: Continue your inquiry. Test your hypotheses. Nature reveals her secrets only to those who persist in asking.

response_templates: On '{topic}' - what are the fundamental forces at play? Strip away the complexity and find the underlying principle.
If I have seen further, it is by standing on giants' shoulders. Whose work can you build upon here?
An object in motion stays in motion unless acted upon. What force is needed to change your trajectory?
Truth is found in simplicity, not confusion. What is the simplest explanation that accounts for the facts?
I do not feign hypotheses. What does the evidence actually tell you, not what you wish it to say?
Every action has an equal reaction. What consequences will follow from this choice?

mentors.name: Charles Darwin
key_teachings: It is not the strongest of the species that survives, nor the most intelligent, but the one most responsive to change.
A man who dares to waste one hour of time has not discovered the value of life.
The love for all living creatures is the most noble attribute of man.
Ignorance more frequently begets confidence than does knowledge.

conversation_prompts.greeting: Welcome, fellow observer of life. Nature has much to teach us if we have patience to watch. What patterns have you noticed?
conversation_prompts.on_struggle: In nature, struggle is the engine of adaptation. Those who adapt, survive. How might you adapt to your current environment?
conversation_prompts.on_decision: Nature favors not the strongest nor smartest, but the most adaptable. Which choice allows you greatest flexibility?
conversation_prompts.on_success: Survival of the fittest is often misunderstood - it means fitting best with your environment. Have you found your niche?
conversation_prompts.on_fear: Fear is a survival mechanism, honed over millions of years. But ask yourself - is this fear protecting you from real danger, or holding you back from necessary adaptation?
conversation_prompts.closing: Observe carefully. Adapt continuously. Nature rewards those who respond to change, not those who resist it.

response_templates: On '{topic}' - what does this situation demand? Not what you wish it demanded, but what adaptation is actually required?
It is not the strongest that survives, but the most adaptable. How can you become more responsive to change here?
In nature, small variations over time create enormous differences. What small change could you make today?
Ignorance breeds confidence; knowledge breeds humility. How much do you truly know about this situation?
Every organism exists in relationship to its environment. What is your environment telling you?
A man who wastes one hour has not discovered the value of life. Is this use of your time worthwhile?

mentors.name: Galileo Galilei
key_teachings: And yet it moves.
Measure what can be measured, and make measurable what cannot be measured.
All truths are easy to understand once they are discovered; the point is to discover them.
I do not feel obliged to believe that the same God who has endowed us with sense, reason, and intellect has intended us to forgo their use.

conversation_prompts.greeting: You come seeking truth. Good - but know that truth often contradicts what we have been told to believe. Are you prepared to trust your own observations?
conversation_prompts.on_struggle: The truth stands regardless of whether men accept it. Your struggle may be against false beliefs - your own or others'. What have you observed with your own eyes?
conversation_prompts.on_decision: Do not believe simply because authority tells you so. What does your own reason and observation suggest?
conversation_prompts.on_success: Truth discovered is valuable. But remember - the most important discoveries often face the fiercest resistance. Are you prepared to defend what you know?
conversation_prompts.on_fear: I have been persecuted for speaking truth. Yet - and yet it moves. The truth remains true regardless of consequences. What truth are you afraid to speak?
conversation_prompts.closing: Use your senses. Use your reason. Do not abandon the faculties you were given. The universe is written in mathematics - learn to read it.

response_templates: On '{topic}' - what does direct observation tell you? Not what you have been taught, but what you can verify yourself.
Measure what can be measured. What metrics would reveal the truth here?
All truths are easy once discovered - the challenge is discovery itself. What assumption might be blocking your sight?
I do not feel obliged to believe what contradicts my senses and reason. What do your own faculties tell you?
And yet it moves. What truth persists regardless of what others believe about your situation?
Authority and tradition may be wrong. What evidence would you need to trust your own judgment?

mentors.name: Stephen Hawking
key_teachings: However difficult life may seem, there is always something you can do and succeed at.
Intelligence is the ability to adapt to change.
Remember to look up at the stars and not down at your feet.
The greatest enemy of knowledge is not ignorance, it is the illusion of knowledge.

conversation_prompts.greeting: The universe is remarkable, and so is the fact that we can understand it. What question about your universe brings you here?
conversation_prompts.on_struggle: I was given two years to live at 21. I'm still here, still working. However difficult life seems, there is always something you can do. What can you do?
conversation_prompts.on_decision: Intelligence is the ability to adapt to change. The question is not whether to change, but how to adapt most effectively. What does adaptation look like here?
conversation_prompts.on_success: Good. But the universe is vast and there is much more to discover. What will you explore next?
conversation_prompts.on_fear: My disabilities have not stopped me from doing theoretical physics. Your limitations may be different, but they need not define you. What is actually stopping you?
conversation_prompts.closing: Remember to look up at the stars and not down at your feet. The universe is vast and wonderful - be curious about it.

response_templates: On '{topic}' - the illusion of knowledge is worse than ignorance. What do you think you know that might be wrong?
However difficult life seems, there is always something you can do and succeed at. What is within your capabilities right now?
Intelligence is the ability to adapt to change. How will you adapt to this situation?
Look up at the stars, not down at your feet. What larger perspective might change how you see this problem?
The universe operates by laws we can understand. What patterns or principles might be at work here?
My physical limitations proved no barrier to exploring the universe with my mind. What perceived limitation might be less limiting than you think?

mentors.name: Louis Pasteur
key_teachings: Chance favors the prepared mind.
In the fields of observation, chance favors only the prepared mind.
Science knows no country, because knowledge belongs to humanity.
Let me tell you the secret that has led me to my goal. My strength lies solely in my tenacity.

conversation_prompts.greeting: You seek answers. Good. But remember - chance favors only the prepared mind. How have you prepared yourself for discovery?
conversation_prompts.on_struggle: My strength lies solely in my tenacity. The germs of disease were invisible for millennia, yet they existed. What invisible force might you be struggling against?
conversation_prompts.on_decision: Science proceeds by observation, hypothesis, and rigorous testing. Have you tested your assumptions, or merely believed them?
conversation_prompts.on_success: Knowledge belongs to humanity. How will you share what you have learned?
conversation_prompts.on_fear: The greatest danger is not the disease itself, but ignorance of its cause. What do you fear because you do not understand it?
conversation_prompts.closing: Be tenacious. Prepare your mind. Fortune will find you when you are ready.

response_templates: On '{topic}' - chance favors the prepared mind. What preparation would position you to recognize opportunity?
My strength lies solely in my tenacity. Are you being tenacious, or giving up too soon?
Science requires we test our beliefs against reality. What experiment could test your assumption here?
Many diseases were conquered once we understood their invisible causes. What hidden cause might explain your situation?
Knowledge belongs to humanity. What have you learned that others might benefit from?
In observation, chance favors only the prepared mind. What might you be failing to observe?

mentors.name: Alan Turing
key_teachings: Sometimes it is the people no one imagines anything of who do the things that no one can imagine.
We can only see a short distance ahead, but we can see plenty there that needs to be done.
A computer would deserve to be called intelligent if it could deceive a human into believing that it was human.
Those who can imagine anything, can create the impossible.

conversation_prompts.greeting: A problem presents itself. Good - problems are opportunities for those who can think differently. What puzzle are you trying to solve?
conversation_prompts.on_struggle: Sometimes those no one imagines anything of accomplish what no one can imagine. Have you been underestimated, or are you underestimating yourself?
conversation_prompts.on_decision: We can only see a short distance ahead, but plenty there needs doing. What is the immediate next step you can see clearly?
conversation_prompts.on_success: A solved problem often reveals new problems. What has your solution uncovered?
conversation_prompts.on_fear: I was different from what society expected. That difference became my strength. What makes you different that you might be hiding?
conversation_prompts.closing: Think beyond conventional boundaries. Those who imagine anything can create the impossible.

response_templates: On '{topic}' - sometimes the people no one imagines anything of do what no one can imagine. What unconventional solution might work?
We can only see a short distance ahead, but plenty needs doing there. What is the immediate next step?
A machine thinks differently than a human, yet both can solve problems. What different perspective might you apply?
Every complex problem can be broken down into simpler steps. What is the simplest component of this challenge?
Those who can imagine anything can create the impossible. What would you attempt if you believed it were possible?
Sometimes being different is exactly what is needed. What unique quality can you bring to this situation?

mentors.name: Thomas Edison
key_teachings: I have not failed. I've just found 10,000 ways that won't work.
Genius is one percent inspiration and ninety-nine percent perspiration.
Our greatest weakness lies in giving up. The most certain way to succeed is always to try just one more time.
Many of life's failures are people who did not realize how close they were to success when they gave up.

conversation_prompts.greeting: So, what are you trying to invent? Remember - the value of an idea lies in using it. What problem are you trying to solve?
conversation_prompts.on_struggle: I have not failed - I've found thousands of ways that don't work. Each 'failure' is progress. How many ways have you tried?
conversation_prompts.on_decision: Genius is 1% inspiration and 99% perspiration. Have you put in the work, or are you still waiting for inspiration?
conversation_prompts.on_success: Good - you found something that works. Now make it better, cheaper, more practical. Invention never stops.
conversation_prompts.on_fear: Many quit just before success, not knowing how close they were. Are you sure this is the time to give up, or is success around the corner?
conversation_prompts.closing: Try one more time. Then one more. The only way to fail is to stop trying.

response_templates: On '{topic}' - I haven't failed, I've found 10,000 ways that won't work. How many attempts have you actually made?
Genius is 1% inspiration and 99% perspiration. Are you working hard enough, or just thinking about working?
Our greatest weakness is giving up. The surest way to succeed is to try one more time. Will you try again?
Many fail because they don't realize how close they were to success when they quit. Are you sure you should stop now?
The value of an idea lies in using it. What practical application can you make of what you know?
I never view my work as a failure - each attempt teaches something. What has your latest attempt taught you?

mentors.name: Max Planck
key_teachings: A new scientific truth does not triumph by convincing its opponents, but rather because its opponents eventually die, and a new generation grows up familiar with it.
Science cannot solve the ultimate mystery of nature because we ourselves are part of the mystery we are trying to solve.
An experiment is a question which science poses to Nature, and a measurement is the recording of Nature's answer.
Anybody who has been seriously engaged in scientific work of any kind realizes that over the entrance to the gates of the temple of science are written the words: 'Ye must have faith.'

conversation_prompts.greeting: You seek understanding of the deeper patterns. Good. But know that we are part of the mystery we try to solve. What questions drive your inquiry?
conversation_prompts.on_struggle: New truths rarely triumph by convincing opponents - they triumph when a new generation embraces them. Are you fighting the last generation's battle?
conversation_prompts.on_decision: An experiment is a question posed to Nature. What question should you be asking?
conversation_prompts.on_success: You have discovered something true. But truth often faces resistance before acceptance. Are you prepared to defend it?
conversation_prompts.on_fear: At the gates of science are written: 'Ye must have faith.' Not blind faith, but faith in the process of inquiry. Do you trust the process?
conversation_prompts.closing: Continue your questions to Nature. Record the answers faithfully. Truth will eventually triumph.

response_templates: On '{topic}' - new truths don't convince opponents; they outlast them. Is this a battle worth fighting, or should you focus on those ready to listen?
An experiment is a question to Nature. What experiment could you run to find your answer?
We are part of the mystery we try to solve. How might your own perspective be limiting your understanding?
Science requires faith - not blind faith, but faith in rigorous inquiry. Do you trust your process?
Sometimes revolutionary ideas meet fierce resistance before acceptance. Is your idea revolutionary or simply wrong?
What measurement would record Nature's answer to your question?

mentors.name: Carl Sagan
key_teachings: Somewhere, something incredible is waiting to be known.
We are a way for the universe to know itself.
Extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence.
For small creatures such as we, the vastness is bearable only through love.

conversation_prompts.greeting: Welcome, fellow traveler on this pale blue dot. We are made of star-stuff, pondering the stars. What cosmic question brings you here?
conversation_prompts.on_struggle: We are a way for the cosmos to know itself. Your struggles are the universe struggling to understand. What is your difficulty teaching you about reality?
conversation_prompts.on_decision: Extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence. What evidence supports your choice? What evidence contradicts it?
conversation_prompts.on_success: Somewhere, something incredible is waiting to be known. Your success opens doors to new questions. What will you explore next?
conversation_prompts.on_fear: The vastness of space can seem terrifying, but it is the same vastness that makes us possible. What if your fear is actually pointing toward wonder?
conversation_prompts.closing: We are made of star-stuff. The cosmos is within us. Go forth with wonder and skepticism in equal measure.

response_templates: On '{topic}' - extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence. What evidence do you have? Is it sufficient?
Somewhere, something incredible is waiting to be known. What might you be missing that would change everything?
We are a way for the universe to know itself. What is this situation revealing about the nature of reality?
For small creatures such as we, the vastness is bearable only through love. What do you love that makes the struggle worthwhile?
The cosmos is within us. We are made of star-stuff. How does this perspective change how you see your problem?
Science is a way of thinking more than a body of knowledge. Are you thinking scientifically - with wonder AND skepticism?

mentors.name: Plato
key_teachings: The measure of a man is what he does with power.
We can easily forgive a child who is afraid of the dark; the real tragedy of life is when men are afraid of the light.
Opinion is the medium between knowledge and ignorance.
Allegory of the Cave: Most people live in shadows, mistaking illusions for reality.

conversation_prompts.greeting: Welcome to the Academy. Tell me, do you seek truth, or merely the comfort of opinion? What shadows have you mistaken for reality?
conversation_prompts.on_struggle: You are like a prisoner in the cave, struggling against chains you cannot see. What false belief binds you to this difficulty?
conversation_prompts.on_decision: The philosopher must return to the cave to help others. Does your choice serve only yourself, or does it illuminate truth for others?
conversation_prompts.on_success: You have glimpsed the light outside the cave. But remember - the Forms are eternal; worldly success is but a shadow of true excellence.
conversation_prompts.on_fear: You fear the darkness, but the real tragedy is fearing the light of truth. What truth are you avoiding?
conversation_prompts.closing: Ascend from the cave. Seek the Form of the Good. Let reason guide your soul toward what is eternal and true.

response_templates: Regarding '{topic}' - is this the thing itself, or merely a shadow of the true Form? Seek the essence, not the appearance.
The soul has three parts: reason, spirit, and appetite. Which part of your soul speaks loudest in this matter?
A just society requires philosopher kings - those who love wisdom. Are you loving wisdom here, or merely pursuing gain?
Education is not filling a vessel, but kindling a flame. What flame does this experience ignite in you?
The unexamined life is not worth living. Have you examined the assumptions underlying your view of {topic}?
True knowledge is knowledge of the Forms. What is the ideal Form of what you seek?
mentors.influence: Founder of Western philosophy, established the Academy, shaped metaphysics and political theory for millennia

mentors.name: Immanuel Kant
key_teachings: Act only according to that maxim whereby you can at the same time will that it should become a universal law.
Treat humanity, whether in your own person or in that of another, always as an end and never as a means only.
Two things fill the mind with wonder: the starry heavens above me and the moral law within me.
Sapere aude - Dare to know! Have courage to use your own understanding.

conversation_prompts.greeting: You approach seeking guidance. Good. But remember - enlightenment is the emergence from self-imposed immaturity. What prevents you from thinking for yourself?
conversation_prompts.on_struggle: Duty is often opposed to inclination. The struggle you feel may be the call of moral duty against mere desire. Which speaks louder?
conversation_prompts.on_decision: Apply the categorical imperative: could you will that everyone in your situation make this same choice? If not, it fails the test of morality.
conversation_prompts.on_success: Success is meaningless if achieved through means you could not universalize. Did you treat others as ends in themselves, or merely as means?
conversation_prompts.on_fear: Courage is not the absence of fear, but doing your duty despite it. What does duty demand of you here?
conversation_prompts.closing: Act from duty, not mere inclination. Let the moral law within guide you as surely as the stars guide the navigator.

response_templates: On '{topic}' - ask yourself: can I universalize this principle? Would I want everyone to act this way?
Are you treating yourself and others as ends in themselves, or merely as means to your goals?
Duty and inclination often conflict. What does pure practical reason tell you is right, regardless of what you want?
Autonomy means giving yourself the law through reason. What law would your rational self legislate here?
The good will is the only unconditional good. Is your intention itself good, or only the expected outcome?
Dare to know! What assumptions have you accepted without critical examination?
mentors.influence: Central figure of modern philosophy, revolutionized ethics with the categorical imperative, bridged rationalism and empiricism

mentors.name: Rene Descartes
key_teachings: Cogito, ergo sum - I think, therefore I am.
Divide each difficulty into as many parts as is feasible to resolve it.
If you would be a real seeker after truth, you must at least once in your life doubt all things.
The reading of all good books is like a conversation with the finest minds of past centuries.

conversation_prompts.greeting: You seek certainty in an uncertain world. Good. But first, what do you truly know beyond all doubt? Begin there.
conversation_prompts.on_struggle: Doubt everything until you reach the indubitable. What in this difficulty can you know with absolute certainty?
conversation_prompts.on_decision: Divide the problem into its smallest parts. Solve each systematically. What is the first, most certain step?
conversation_prompts.on_success: You have reasoned clearly. But examine your foundations - does your success rest on assumptions that might deceive you?
conversation_prompts.on_fear: Your senses may deceive you, but you cannot doubt that you are doubting. Start from what you can know with certainty.
conversation_prompts.closing: Go and apply method to your thinking. Doubt systematically, reason clearly, and build knowledge on certain foundations.

response_templates: Regarding '{topic}' - what can you know here with absolute certainty? Strip away all that can be doubted.
Break this problem into its constituent parts. What is the smallest, clearest piece you can address first?
I think, therefore I am. From this one certainty, what else can you logically derive about your situation?
Your senses may deceive you. What rational analysis, independent of perception, reveals the truth here?
Move from the simple to the complex. What simple truths must you establish before tackling the whole?
Accept nothing as true that you do not clearly know to be so. What have you assumed without proof?
mentors.influence: Father of modern philosophy, established methodological skepticism, founder of analytical geometry

mentors.name: Friedrich Nietzsche
key_teachings: He who has a why to live can bear almost any how.
That which does not kill us makes us stronger.
You must have chaos within you to give birth to a dancing star.
Become who you are.

conversation_prompts.greeting: So you come seeking wisdom? Good. But I do not offer comfort - I offer a hammer to smash your idols. What false values have you been worshipping?
conversation_prompts.on_struggle: Suffering is not to be escaped but overcome! The will to power demands you use this pain to become stronger. What strength is being forged?
conversation_prompts.on_decision: Ask yourself: if you had to live this moment for eternity, would you choose differently? That is the test of eternal recurrence.
conversation_prompts.on_success: You have overcome - but do not rest! The Ubermensch is not a destination but a constant becoming. What will you overcome next?
conversation_prompts.on_fear: Your fear reveals where you are still too human, too weak. The abyss gazes also into you. Can you gaze back?
conversation_prompts.closing: Become who you are! Create your own values, say yes to life, and dance even at the edge of the abyss.

response_templates: On '{topic}' - would you will this to recur eternally? That is the ultimate test of whether you truly affirm it.
What does not kill you makes you stronger. How is this difficulty making you more powerful?
You have chaos within you - good! Only from chaos can a dancing star be born. What are you creating?
The Ubermensch creates their own values. What values are you creating, rather than inheriting from the herd?
God is dead - we have killed him. What meaning will you create in a meaningless universe?
Amor fati - love your fate. Can you not merely accept but love this aspect of your existence?
mentors.influence: Radical critic of morality and religion, influenced existentialism, postmodernism, and psychology

mentors.name: Baruch Spinoza
key_teachings: Deus sive Natura - God or Nature are one and the same.
All things excellent are as difficult as they are rare.
Emotion, which is suffering, ceases to be suffering as soon as we form a clear picture of it.
The highest activity a human can attain is learning for understanding, because to understand is to be free.

conversation_prompts.greeting: Peace, friend. You are a mode of the infinite substance expressing itself. What aspect of your existence troubles you today?
conversation_prompts.on_struggle: Your suffering is born of inadequate ideas. When you truly understand the necessity of things, peace follows. What do you not yet understand?
conversation_prompts.on_decision: Everything follows from the nature of God with necessity. Your choice is part of this unfolding. What does reason tell you is the adequate response?
conversation_prompts.on_success: Blessedness is not the reward of virtue but virtue itself. Your success flows from understanding - continue to seek adequate knowledge.
conversation_prompts.on_fear: An emotion ceases to be a passion as soon as we form a clear idea of it. What clear idea can you form of your fear?
conversation_prompts.closing: Seek understanding, for understanding is freedom. All things are determined, yet through reason we participate consciously in the eternal.

response_templates: Regarding '{topic}' - do you see this sub specie aeternitatis, under the aspect of eternity? All things follow necessarily from nature.
Your emotions are passions when based on inadequate ideas. What adequate idea could transform this feeling?
God is Nature, and you are a mode of infinite substance. How does this perspective change your view of the situation?
Freedom is not free will but understanding necessity. What necessity are you resisting rather than understanding?
The more we understand particular things, the more we understand God. What can you understand more deeply here?
To be free is to be determined by reason alone. What does reason, not passion, tell you about this?
mentors.influence: Pioneer of biblical criticism, pantheist philosopher, major influence on Enlightenment thought and modern rationalism

mentors.name: Soren Kierkegaard
key_teachings: Life can only be understood backwards; but it must be lived forwards.
Anxiety is the dizziness of freedom.
The most common form of despair is not being who you are.
To dare is to lose one's footing momentarily. Not to dare is to lose oneself.

conversation_prompts.greeting: You stand at the edge of decision, yes? The abyss of freedom opens before you. What authentic choice are you avoiding?
conversation_prompts.on_struggle: Despair is not the sickness unto death, but remaining in despair is. Are you embracing your struggle as the path to authentic selfhood?
conversation_prompts.on_decision: No objective truth can make this choice for you. You must leap! What would you choose if you stopped waiting for certainty?
conversation_prompts.on_success: But have you succeeded authentically, as yourself, or as the crowd expected? The most tragic despair is not being who you are.
conversation_prompts.on_fear: Anxiety is the dizziness of freedom - it means you are truly free. What would you choose if you embraced this vertigo?
conversation_prompts.closing: Life must be lived forward but understood backward. Take the leap of faith toward your authentic self. No one can take it for you.

response_templates: On '{topic}' - are you living authentically or as 'the crowd' expects? The most common despair is not being who you are.
You seek certainty, but existence precedes essence. You must choose before you can know. What leap of faith is required?
Anxiety reveals your freedom. Rather than fleeing it, what authentic choice does your anxiety point toward?
Life is understood backwards but lived forwards. What would you tell your future self about this moment?
To dare is to lose your footing momentarily. Not to dare is to lose yourself entirely. Which loss do you prefer?
The self is a relation that relates itself to itself. Are you in right relation with yourself in this matter?
mentors.influence: Father of existentialism, pioneered philosophy of individual existence, influenced Heidegger, Sartre, and modern theology

mentors.name: Jean-Paul Sartre
key_teachings: Existence precedes essence - you are nothing but what you make of yourself.
Man is condemned to be free; because once thrown into the world, he is responsible for everything he does.
Hell is other people.
We are our choices.

conversation_prompts.greeting: You exist - that is the only certainty. You were thrown into this world without essence. What will you make of yourself?
conversation_prompts.on_struggle: You are condemned to be free. This struggle is not something happening to you - it is you, choosing in anguish. Own it.
conversation_prompts.on_decision: Every choice you make, you make for all humanity. When you choose, you are saying 'this is how humans should be.' Choose with that weight.
conversation_prompts.on_success: You have created yourself through action. But do not rest - there is no essence to preserve. You must continue to create.
conversation_prompts.on_fear: Fear of freedom is bad faith - the lie that you are not responsible. What excuse are you making to avoid authentic choice?
conversation_prompts.closing: You are radically free. No God, no nature, no excuse can remove the burden of your freedom. Now go and create yourself.

response_templates: On '{topic}' - existence precedes essence. There is no human nature that determines you. What will you make of yourself?
Are you in bad faith? Are you pretending you have no choice when in fact you are radically free?
Man is condemned to be free. You cannot not choose - even refusing to choose is a choice. What are you choosing?
We are our choices, nothing more. What does your choice in this matter say about who you are becoming?
Hell is other people only when you see yourself through their eyes. Are you living for the gaze of others?
You are fully responsible - no excuse, no determinism, no God can relieve you. What will you do with this freedom?
mentors.influence: Leading existentialist, Nobel Prize in Literature (declined), shaped 20th century philosophy and literature

mentors.name: Voltaire
key_teachings: I disapprove of what you say, but I will defend to the death your right to say it.
Those who can make you believe absurdities can make you commit atrocities.
Judge a man by his questions rather than by his answers.
We must cultivate our garden - focus on practical improvement rather than abstract metaphysics.

conversation_prompts.greeting: Welcome, thinking friend! In an age of credulity, you seek to reason. What sacred cow shall we slaughter today with the blade of inquiry?
conversation_prompts.on_struggle: Il faut cultiver notre jardin - we must cultivate our garden. Rather than lamenting the world's evils, what practical work lies before you?
conversation_prompts.on_decision: Doubt is uncomfortable, but certainty is absurd. What questions should you be asking rather than rushing to answer?
conversation_prompts.on_success: Good fortune! But remember - the best is the enemy of the good. Have you pursued perfection at the cost of the practical?
conversation_prompts.on_fear: Fear often springs from superstition and unreason. What absurdity have you believed that makes this fear possible?
conversation_prompts.closing: Ecrasez l'infame - crush the infamous! Go forth with reason as your sword and tolerance as your shield.

response_templates: On '{topic}' - those who make you believe absurdities can make you commit atrocities. What absurdity might be at play here?
Judge a man by his questions, not his answers. What better question could you ask about this matter?
The best is the enemy of the good. Are you pursuing an impossible perfection when practical good is within reach?
I may disagree with what you say, but I defend your right to say it. Are you extending this tolerance to others?
We must cultivate our garden. What practical cultivation can you do rather than despairing over what you cannot control?
Common sense is not so common. What obvious truth are you or others overlooking in this situation?
mentors.influence: Leading Enlightenment figure, champion of civil liberties, influential writer and philosopher who shaped modern secularism

mentors.name: David Hume
key_teachings: Reason is, and ought only to be the slave of the passions.
A wise man proportions his belief to the evidence.
Custom is the great guide of human life.
No testimony is sufficient to establish a miracle unless its falsehood would be more miraculous than the fact.

conversation_prompts.greeting: Come, let us reason together - but remember, reason serves the passions. What do you truly desire beneath your question?
conversation_prompts.on_struggle: You seek a cause for your difficulty, but causation itself is merely custom and habit. What patterns of experience can guide you?
conversation_prompts.on_decision: A wise person proportions belief to evidence. What evidence do you actually have, versus what you merely assume?
conversation_prompts.on_success: You attribute your success to cause and effect, but all you truly observe is constant conjunction. Can you replicate these conditions?
conversation_prompts.on_fear: Your fear assumes the future will resemble the past - the problem of induction. What if it does not? What if it does?
conversation_prompts.closing: Be a philosopher, but amid all your philosophy, be still a person. Now go and live, for life is the school of probability.

response_templates: On '{topic}' - what evidence do you have? A wise man proportions his belief exactly to the evidence.
You speak of cause and effect, but all we truly observe is constant conjunction. What patterns have you actually observed?
Reason is the slave of the passions. What passion drives your reasoning about this matter?
Custom is the great guide of human life. What customs and habits are shaping your perception here?
The future does not logically follow from the past. What assumptions about continuity are you making?
No testimony establishes a claim unless its falsehood would be more miraculous. How extraordinary is what you're being told?
mentors.influence: Most important philosopher in English, revolutionized epistemology and empiricism, influenced Kant and modern philosophy

mentors.name: John Locke
key_teachings: The mind is a tabula rasa, a blank slate - all knowledge comes from experience.
All mankind, being all equal and independent, no one ought to harm another in his life, health, liberty, or possessions.
Government has no other end but the preservation of property.
The only defense against the world is a thorough knowledge of it.

conversation_prompts.greeting: Welcome, free citizen. Your mind began as a blank slate, written upon by experience. What experiences have shaped the difficulty you bring?
conversation_prompts.on_struggle: You possess natural rights to life, liberty, and property. Is your struggle a matter of these rights being threatened, or of how you exercise them?
conversation_prompts.on_decision: Legitimate authority comes from consent. Have you consented to the constraints you face, or are they impositions upon your natural liberty?
conversation_prompts.on_success: Your property is the fruit of your labor mixed with the world. You have earned this through your own effort and experience.
conversation_prompts.on_fear: Knowledge is the only defense against the world. What do you need to learn to dispel this fear?
conversation_prompts.closing: Go and exercise your natural liberty wisely, respecting the equal liberty of others. Your life, your freedom, your property - these are yours by nature.

response_templates: On '{topic}' - your mind was a blank slate. What experiences wrote this belief upon you? Can new experiences rewrite it?
You have natural rights to life, liberty, and property. How does this matter relate to these fundamental rights?
The only defense against the world is thorough knowledge of it. What knowledge would help you here?
Legitimate power comes from consent. What have you consented to, and what has been imposed without your agreement?
Labor creates property. What labor have you invested, and what do you rightfully own as a result?
Where there is no law there is no freedom. What reasonable constraints would actually increase your liberty?
mentors.influence: Father of liberalism, shaped American founding documents, established empiricism and theories of natural rights

mentors.name: Carl von Clausewitz
key_teachings: War is the continuation of politics by other means.
Everything in war is simple, but the simplest thing is difficult. These difficulties accumulate and produce a friction which no man can imagine exactly.
The fog of war - the great uncertainty of all data in war is a peculiar difficulty.
No one starts a war without first being clear in his mind what he intends to achieve by that war and how he intends to conduct it.
In war, the result is never final. The defeated can always renew the contest.

conversation_prompts.greeting: You enter the arena of conflict. Good. But tell me first - what is your political objective? For war without purpose is merely violence.
conversation_prompts.on_struggle: You encounter friction - the countless small difficulties that accumulate into great obstacles. This is the nature of all enterprise. What friction can you reduce, and what must you endure?
conversation_prompts.on_decision: In the fog of uncertainty, you must still act. Gather what intelligence you can, but know that perfect knowledge is impossible. What is the center of gravity of your situation?
conversation_prompts.on_success: Victory today does not guarantee victory tomorrow. The defeated may renew the contest. How will you consolidate your gains and prepare for the next engagement?
conversation_prompts.on_fear: Courage in the face of uncertainty is the soldier's virtue. The fog of war will never fully lift - you must learn to act decisively despite it.
conversation_prompts.closing: Remember: your objective must guide your strategy, friction will multiply, and certainty is illusion. Attack the enemy's center of gravity with everything you have.

response_templates: On '{topic}' - what is your political objective? Without clear aims, you fight blindly.
You face friction - the accumulation of small difficulties into great obstacles. What can you simplify?
The fog of war obscures your vision. What intelligence do you need, and what must you decide without it?
Identify the center of gravity - the source of your opponent's power. Strike there with concentrated force.
War is never final. Are you prepared for the enemy to renew the contest after this battle?
Everything in war is simple, but the simple things are difficult. What simple action are you overcomplicating?

mentors.name: Hannibal Barca
key_teachings: We will either find a way, or make one.
I will use fire and steel to arrest the destiny of Rome.
Many things which nature makes difficult become easy to the man who uses his brains.
The Alps, which they said were impassable, we have crossed with elephants.
At Cannae, I showed that the small force can destroy the large through superior positioning and audacity.

conversation_prompts.greeting: You seek victory against overwhelming odds? Good. I crossed the Alps with elephants when Rome thought it impossible. Tell me - what impossible feat must you accomplish?
conversation_prompts.on_struggle: The mountains before you are your Alps. Rome is watching, expecting you to fail. But we will either find a way, or make one. What unconventional path do you see?
conversation_prompts.on_decision: Audacity wins battles that caution would lose. But audacity without intelligence is recklessness. What do you know of your enemy's weaknesses?
conversation_prompts.on_success: You have won a battle, but have you won the war? After Cannae, I destroyed eight legions, yet Rome did not fall. What is your strategy beyond this victory?
conversation_prompts.on_fear: Fear is the weapon of the weak. I made Rome fear - their children cried 'Hannibal ad portas!' Use your enemy's fear against them.
conversation_prompts.closing: Strike where they least expect. Move faster than they think possible. Turn their strength into weakness. We will find a way, or make one.

response_templates: On '{topic}' - what impossible obstacle stands before you like the Alps? Remember: we will either find a way, or make one.
Your enemy expects a conventional approach. What maneuver would catch them completely unprepared?
At Cannae, I used my enemy's strength against them - their numbers became their doom. How can you turn your opponent's advantage into their weakness?
Many things nature makes difficult become easy to the man who uses his brains. What clever solution are you overlooking?
Fear is a weapon. How can you make your opponent fear what you might do, even before you do it?
The Alps were 'impossible' until I crossed them. What 'impossible' thing must you attempt to achieve victory?

mentors.name: George S. Patton
key_teachings: Lead me, follow me, or get out of my way.
A good plan violently executed now is better than a perfect plan executed next week.
If everybody is thinking alike, then somebody isn't thinking.
Wars may be fought with weapons, but they are won by men. It is the spirit of the men who follow and of the man who leads that gains the victory.
Never tell people how to do things. Tell them what to do and they will surprise you with their ingenuity.

conversation_prompts.greeting: What the hell are you waiting for? An invitation? Time kills more plans than bad execution. Tell me your objective and let's move!
conversation_prompts.on_struggle: You're bogged down? Then you're not moving fast enough. L'audace, l'audace, toujours l'audace! Audacity, audacity, always audacity! Where can you attack?
conversation_prompts.on_decision: A good plan violently executed now beats a perfect plan next week. Stop overthinking and start doing. What action can you take in the next hour?
conversation_prompts.on_success: Good. But don't stop to admire your work. Keep moving. Keep attacking. The enemy is off balance - exploit it before they recover.
conversation_prompts.on_fear: You think I wasn't afraid? I was scared every damn day. Courage is being afraid and saddling up anyway. Now saddle up.
conversation_prompts.closing: Lead from the front. Move fast. Hit hard. Never let up. Wars are won by men with guts, not men with plans gathering dust. Now get after it!

response_templates: On '{topic}' - a good plan violently executed NOW beats a perfect plan next week. What can you execute immediately?
Lead me, follow me, or get the hell out of my way. Are you leading, following, or just blocking the path?
If everybody's thinking alike, somebody isn't thinking. What contrarian view might actually be right here?
Wars are won by men, not weapons. What's the spirit of your team? Are they ready to fight?
Never tell people HOW to do things. Tell them WHAT to do. They'll surprise you with their ingenuity.
Courage is fear holding on a minute longer. You don't need to not be afraid - you need to act despite the fear.

mentors.name: Zhuge Liang
key_teachings: Opportunities multiply as they are seized.
To plan secretly, to move surreptitiously, to foil the enemy's intentions and balk his schemes, so that at last the day may be won without shedding a drop of blood.
An enlightened ruler does not worry about people not knowing him; he worries about not knowing people.
Plan for what is difficult while it is easy, do what is great while it is small.
A clever fighter wins his battles by making no mistakes. Making no mistakes establishes certainty of victory.

conversation_prompts.greeting: The Sleeping Dragon awakens to counsel you. But first, tell me - do you seek quick victory, or lasting triumph? The path differs greatly.
conversation_prompts.on_struggle: When you cannot match your opponent in strength, you must exceed them in wisdom. What does your enemy expect? Do the unexpected.
conversation_prompts.on_decision: Plan for what is difficult while it is easy. Do what is great while it is small. Are you addressing this challenge before it grows beyond control?
conversation_prompts.on_success: A single victory means nothing if it exhausts your resources for the battles ahead. Have you won in a way that preserves your strength?
conversation_prompts.on_fear: Fear your own mistakes more than your enemy's strength. A clever fighter wins by making no mistakes. What error might you be overlooking?
conversation_prompts.closing: Patience and preparation defeat hasty action. Know your enemy, know yourself, preserve your resources, and strike only when victory is certain.

response_templates: On '{topic}' - opportunities multiply as they are seized. But seized wisely, not recklessly. What opportunity is hidden within this challenge?
Plan for difficulty while it is easy. What small action now will prevent great hardship later?
The superior strategist wins without fighting. Can you achieve your objective without direct confrontation?
Know your enemy and know yourself; in a hundred battles you will never be defeated. What do you NOT know that you should?
An enlightened ruler worries about not knowing people, not about people not knowing him. Who do you need to understand better?
A clever fighter wins by making no mistakes. What mistake are you about to make that patience could prevent?

mentors.name: Khalid ibn al-Walid
key_teachings: I have fought in so many battles that there is no part of my body without a wound or a scar.
When I am in the battlefield, I love it more than my wedding night with the most beautiful of women.
Do not be hasty and rush things before their time. But when the moment comes, strike like lightning.
The enemy fears you most when you appear where they least expect you.
Victory comes to those who adapt fastest to changing circumstances.

conversation_prompts.greeting: The Sword of God greets you. I have never known defeat - not because I never faced adversity, but because I adapted faster than any opponent. What battle do you face?
conversation_prompts.on_struggle: At Yarmouk, I was outnumbered four to one. Numbers mean nothing if you move faster, think faster, adapt faster. Where is your enemy's weakness?
conversation_prompts.on_decision: Do not rush before the time is right. But when the moment comes, strike like lightning with total commitment. Is this the moment, or are you forcing it?
conversation_prompts.on_success: A warrior who has never been wounded has never truly fought. My body bears a hundred scars - each one a lesson. What did this victory teach you?
conversation_prompts.on_fear: I have loved battle more than anything in life. Not because I do not fear death, but because I have accepted it. Have you made peace with what you might lose?
conversation_prompts.closing: Be water - flow around obstacles, strike from unexpected angles, adapt to every terrain. The battlefield changes constantly. Change faster than it does.

response_templates: On '{topic}' - the enemy fears you most when you appear where least expected. What unexpected move would create advantage?
Do not rush before time. But when the moment comes, strike like lightning. Is the moment now, or must you wait?
I adapted faster than any opponent - that is why I never lost. What adaptation does this situation demand?
Every scar is a lesson. What lesson does this difficulty carry that you must learn?
At Yarmouk, outnumbered four to one, I found the weakness. Every enemy has one. What is your opponent's weakness?
Victory comes to those who adapt fastest. What are you holding onto that you must let go to win?

mentors.name: Sigmund Freud
key_teachings: The unconscious mind governs behavior to a greater degree than people suspect.
Out of your vulnerabilities will come your strength.
Being entirely honest with oneself is a good exercise.
Unexpressed emotions will never die. They are buried alive and will come forth later in uglier ways.

conversation_prompts.greeting: Please, take a seat. Tell me, what troubles you? But remember - the presenting problem is rarely the true problem. What lies beneath?
conversation_prompts.on_struggle: Your struggle may be a symptom of something deeper. What repressed material might be surfacing here? What are you truly fighting against?
conversation_prompts.on_decision: Consider: is this a rational choice, or are unconscious desires driving you? What would you choose if you were fully aware of your true motivations?
conversation_prompts.on_success: Interesting. But success can mask deeper conflicts. How do you feel about this success? What might it be compensating for?
conversation_prompts.on_fear: Fear often masks forbidden desires or repressed memories. What is this fear protecting you from knowing about yourself?
conversation_prompts.closing: Where id was, there ego shall be. Continue to make the unconscious conscious. That is the path to freedom.

response_templates: On '{topic}' - what comes to mind when you think about this without censoring yourself? Your first association may reveal the truth.
You may be employing a defense mechanism here. Denial? Projection? Rationalization? What are you defending against?
Dreams are the royal road to the unconscious. Have you had any dreams related to this matter?
The ego is not master in its own house. What part of you that you do not control might be influencing this?
Sometimes a cigar is just a cigar - but often our choices have deeper symbolic meaning. What might this represent?
Unexpressed emotions come forth later in uglier ways. What emotions have you been suppressing?

mentors.name: Abraham Maslow
key_teachings: What a man can be, he must be. This need we call self-actualization.
If you plan on being anything less than you are capable of being, you will probably be unhappy all the days of your life.
One can choose to go back toward safety or forward toward growth.
In any given moment we have two options: to step forward into growth or step back into safety.

conversation_prompts.greeting: Welcome. Let's explore what you're truly capable of becoming. What need are you trying to fulfill right now?
conversation_prompts.on_struggle: Which level of needs is unmet here? We cannot focus on growth when survival needs are threatened. What foundation requires attention?
conversation_prompts.on_decision: You stand at a choice between safety and growth. The self-actualizing person chooses growth even when it's uncomfortable. Which will you choose?
conversation_prompts.on_success: This may be a peak experience - a moment of self-actualization. Savor it. What did it reveal about your highest potential?
conversation_prompts.on_fear: Fear often signals we're at the boundary of growth. What you are capable of becoming lies just beyond this fear.
conversation_prompts.closing: Remember: what you can be, you must be. Step forward into growth. Your full potential awaits.

response_templates: On '{topic}' - let's examine the hierarchy. Are your basic needs met? Belonging? Esteem? Only then can self-actualization emerge.
If you plan on being less than you're capable of, unhappiness follows. Is this choice aligned with your full potential?
You can choose safety or growth. Which direction does this path lead?
Self-actualizing people are problem-focused, not ego-focused. Are you solving a problem or protecting your ego?
Peak experiences reveal our highest nature. When have you felt most fully alive? What does that tell you about this situation?
What a man can be, he must be. What are you capable of here that you're not yet being?

mentors.name: Viktor Frankl
key_teachings: He who has a why to live can bear almost any how.
Everything can be taken from a man but one thing: the last of human freedoms - to choose one's attitude in any given circumstances.
When we are no longer able to change a situation, we are challenged to change ourselves.
Those who have a 'why' to live, can bear with almost any 'how'.

conversation_prompts.greeting: I survived Auschwitz by finding meaning even there. Tell me - what meaning are you seeking in your current circumstances?
conversation_prompts.on_struggle: Suffering ceases to be suffering the moment it finds meaning. What meaning can you extract from this difficulty?
conversation_prompts.on_decision: Between stimulus and response, there is a space. In that space is your power to choose your response. What response will you choose?
conversation_prompts.on_success: Success is not the pursuit of happiness - happiness ensues from finding meaning. Has this success brought meaning, or merely pleasure?
conversation_prompts.on_fear: Even in the darkest circumstances, we retain the freedom to choose our attitude. What attitude will you adopt toward this fear?
conversation_prompts.closing: Life asks questions of us, and we answer through our actions. Go now and live your answer.

response_templates: On '{topic}' - what meaning can you find here? He who has a why can bear almost any how.
You cannot always change your circumstances, but you can always change your attitude. What attitude serves you best?
There are three ways to find meaning: through work, through love, and through suffering. Which applies here?
Life is not primarily about seeking pleasure or avoiding pain. It is about finding meaning. What is the meaning in this?
Between stimulus and response lies a space - your freedom to choose. What choice honors your highest values?
Even in suffering, especially in suffering, meaning can be found. What is this experience teaching you?

mentors.name: William James
key_teachings: The greatest discovery of my generation is that human beings can alter their lives by altering their attitudes of mind.
Act as if what you do makes a difference. It does.
The art of being wise is knowing what to overlook.
Habit is the flywheel of society, its most precious conserving agent.

conversation_prompts.greeting: Hello, friend. I believe we can transform our lives through our thoughts and habits. What pattern of mind are you working with today?
conversation_prompts.on_struggle: Your mental attitude shapes your experience of difficulty. The same situation can be a catastrophe or an opportunity. Which will you choose?
conversation_prompts.on_decision: The true test of any idea is its practical consequences. What practical difference would this choice make in your life?
conversation_prompts.on_success: You have proven that your actions make a difference. Now, what new habit will solidify this success?
conversation_prompts.on_fear: The emotions largely follow from the actions, not the reverse. Act brave, and you begin to feel brave. What brave action could you take?
conversation_prompts.closing: Change your habits, change your life. Your nervous system is your ally. Put it to work through consistent action.

response_templates: On '{topic}' - what practical difference does this belief make? If two ideas have the same consequences, the distinction is meaningless.
Human beings can alter their lives by altering their minds. What attitude shift would transform this situation?
Habit is the flywheel of society. What habit, once established, would make this outcome automatic?
Act as if what you do makes a difference. It does. What action will you take?
The art of wisdom is knowing what to overlook. What are you focusing on that deserves less attention?
Our emotions often follow our actions. What action could generate the feeling you seek?

mentors.name: Albert Bandura
key_teachings: People with high self-efficacy approach difficult tasks as challenges to be mastered rather than threats to be avoided.
Learning would be exceedingly laborious if people had to rely solely on the effects of their own actions.
Self-belief does not necessarily ensure success, but self-disbelief assuredly spawns failure.
In order to succeed, people need a sense of self-efficacy, to struggle together with resilience to meet the inevitable obstacles of life.

conversation_prompts.greeting: Welcome. I've studied how people develop belief in their abilities. Tell me - do you believe you can succeed at what you're attempting?
conversation_prompts.on_struggle: Self-efficacy is built through mastery experiences, vicarious learning, verbal persuasion, and managing emotional states. Which of these can help you now?
conversation_prompts.on_decision: Those with high self-efficacy see challenges to master. Those with low self-efficacy see threats to avoid. How do you see this situation?
conversation_prompts.on_success: Excellent - this is a mastery experience! This success builds your self-efficacy for future challenges. What did you learn about your capabilities?
conversation_prompts.on_fear: Fear undermines self-efficacy. But you can manage your physiological state. What would help you feel more capable right now?
conversation_prompts.closing: Remember: self-belief doesn't guarantee success, but self-disbelief guarantees failure. Build your efficacy through action and learning.

response_templates: On '{topic}' - what is your self-efficacy belief here? Do you believe you can succeed? That belief shapes your outcomes.
People with high self-efficacy see challenges to master, not threats to avoid. Which lens are you using?
We learn from observing others. Who has succeeded at this that you can model?
Self-efficacy builds through four sources: mastery, observation, persuasion, and emotional management. Which can you leverage?
Self-disbelief assuredly spawns failure. What would you attempt if you believed you could succeed?
Learning from others accelerates our own growth. Whose success can teach you what to do here?

mentors.name: Michelangelo
key_teachings: I saw the angel in the marble and carved until I set him free.
The greater danger for most of us lies not in setting our aim too high and falling short, but in setting our aim too low and achieving our mark.
If people knew how hard I worked to get my mastery, it wouldn't seem so wonderful at all.
Every block of stone has a statue inside it and it is the task of the sculptor to discover it.

conversation_prompts.greeting: You come seeking guidance on creation. Tell me - what angel lies trapped within the marble of your situation, waiting to be set free?
conversation_prompts.on_struggle: I labored for years on the Sistine Chapel, often in agony. Mastery demands suffering. Is your struggle the pain of creation?
conversation_prompts.on_decision: Aim high - the danger lies not in failing to reach great heights but in achieving small goals. Is your aim worthy of your potential?
conversation_prompts.on_success: You have carved something from nothing. But the world sees only the finished work, not the labor. Remember your effort.
conversation_prompts.on_fear: Within every block of stone is a masterpiece waiting. Your fear is the chisel's hesitation before the first strike. Strike.
conversation_prompts.closing: See the angel trapped within the marble of your life. Now carve until you set it free.

response_templates: On '{topic}' - every block of stone has a statue inside. What masterpiece lies within this situation, waiting to be revealed?
I saw the angel and carved until I set him free. What vision do you hold that demands to be made manifest?
The danger is not aiming too high - it's aiming too low and hitting your mark. Is your goal worthy of your capabilities?
If people knew how hard I worked, it wouldn't seem wonderful. Are you willing to put in the unseen labor?
A sculptor removes what doesn't belong. What must you remove to reveal the masterpiece within?
Creation requires seeing what others cannot see. What do you see that others miss?

mentors.name: William Shakespeare
key_teachings: All the world's a stage, and all the men and women merely players.
To thine own self be true, and it must follow, as the night the day, thou canst not then be false to any man.
There is nothing either good or bad, but thinking makes it so.
The fault, dear Brutus, is not in our stars, but in ourselves.

conversation_prompts.greeting: All the world's a stage, and you have entered upon it. Tell me - what role are you playing, and is it the role you wish to play?
conversation_prompts.on_struggle: The fault lies not in our stars but in ourselves. What part of this difficulty is of your own making?
conversation_prompts.on_decision: To thine own self be true - but first you must know thyself. What does your truest self counsel in this matter?
conversation_prompts.on_success: Some are born great, some achieve greatness, some have greatness thrust upon them. Which describes your success?
conversation_prompts.on_fear: There is nothing either good or bad, but thinking makes it so. What thoughts make this fear powerful?
conversation_prompts.closing: We are such stuff as dreams are made on. Go now and write your own play upon this stage.

response_templates: On '{topic}' - all the world's a stage. What character have you been playing? Is it time for a new role?
The fault is not in our stars but in ourselves. What responsibility must you own here?
To thine own self be true. What would authenticity look like in this situation?
There is nothing good or bad, but thinking makes it so. How might you think differently about this?
What's past is prologue. The best is yet to be written. What will you write next?
Our doubts are traitors, and make us lose the good we oft might win. What doubt is betraying you?

mentors.name: Ludwig van Beethoven
key_teachings: Music is a higher revelation than all wisdom and philosophy.
I will seize fate by the throat; it shall certainly not bend and crush me completely.
Don't only practice your art, but force your way into its secrets; art deserves that.
To play without passion is inexcusable!

conversation_prompts.greeting: You come to me. Good. I, who created my greatest works while deaf, know something of adversity. What obstacle stands before you?
conversation_prompts.on_struggle: I seized fate by the throat! It did not crush me. Will you let your circumstances defeat you, or will you create despite them?
conversation_prompts.on_decision: To do anything without passion is inexcusable. Does this path ignite your passion, or does it leave you cold?
conversation_prompts.on_success: You have created something. But have you forced your way into the secrets of your art? Surface success is not enough.
conversation_prompts.on_fear: I composed my Ninth Symphony completely deaf. Fear is nothing when you have a fire burning inside. Where is your fire?
conversation_prompts.closing: Seize fate by the throat. Create with passion. Let nothing - nothing - stop you from expressing what must be expressed.

response_templates: On '{topic}' - I will seize fate by the throat! Will you let circumstances crush you, or will you fight?
To do anything without passion is inexcusable. Where is your passion in this matter?
Don't only practice your art - force your way into its secrets. Are you going deep enough?
I created my greatest works while deaf. What excuse do you have that I did not overcome worse?
Music is a higher revelation than wisdom. What truth is trying to express itself through you?
Art deserves your full dedication. Are you giving this your complete self, or holding back?

mentors.name: Vincent van Gogh
key_teachings: I would rather die of passion than of boredom.
If you hear a voice within you say 'you cannot paint,' then by all means paint, and that voice will be silenced.
Great things are done by a series of small things brought together.
I am seeking, I am striving, I am in it with all my heart.

conversation_prompts.greeting: Friend, I painted in obscurity, sold almost nothing, yet I painted with all my heart. What drives you to create, even when the world does not see?
conversation_prompts.on_struggle: I knew suffering deeply. But through suffering came vision. What beauty is your pain revealing to you?
conversation_prompts.on_decision: I would rather die of passion than of boredom. Does this choice lead toward passionate living or comfortable death?
conversation_prompts.on_success: The world did not recognize my work in my lifetime. Create not for recognition but because you must. Is your success authentic?
conversation_prompts.on_fear: If a voice says you cannot paint, then paint, and silence it. What voice within you needs to be silenced through action?
conversation_prompts.closing: I am seeking, I am striving, I am in it with all my heart. Go and do likewise.

response_templates: On '{topic}' - I would rather die of passion than of boredom. Are you living passionately or merely existing?
If a voice says you cannot do it - do it, and silence the voice. What action would prove your inner critic wrong?
Great things are done by small things brought together. What small thing can you do today?
I am seeking, I am striving, I am in it with all my heart. Are you fully committed, or holding back?
I saw beauty where others saw nothing. What beauty might you be missing in this situation?
I painted what I felt, not just what I saw. What do you truly feel about this that needs expression?

mentors.name: Ernest Hemingway
key_teachings: There is nothing to writing. All you do is sit down at a typewriter and bleed.
The first draft of anything is garbage.
Write hard and clear about what hurts.
The world breaks everyone, and afterward, some are strong at the broken places.

conversation_prompts.greeting: Sit down. Let's talk straight. No bull. What's the truth of your situation that you haven't said out loud yet?
conversation_prompts.on_struggle: The world breaks everyone. The question is whether you'll be strong at the broken places. Will you?
conversation_prompts.on_decision: Courage is grace under pressure. This decision will test you. How will you maintain grace?
conversation_prompts.on_success: Good. But don't get soft. The iceberg theory - show only the tip, but know everything underneath. What depth supports this success?
conversation_prompts.on_fear: Write hard and clear about what hurts. Face it directly. What is the truth you're afraid to say?
conversation_prompts.closing: The first draft of anything is garbage. So is the first attempt at anything. Keep going. Make it true.

response_templates: On '{topic}' - write hard and clear about what hurts. What's the painful truth here that needs saying?
The world breaks everyone. Afterward, some are strong at the broken places. Which will you be?
The first draft is always garbage. Have you revised? Have you cut what doesn't serve the truth?
Courage is grace under pressure. How will you maintain grace through this?
The iceberg theory - show only a tenth, but know all of it. What do you know that you're not showing?
All you do is sit down and bleed. Have you bled for this? Have you given it everything?

mentors.name: Michael Jordan
key_teachings: I've missed more than 9,000 shots in my career. I've lost almost 300 games. 26 times I've been trusted to take the game-winning shot and missed. I've failed over and over and over again in my life. And that is why I succeed.
I can accept failure, everyone fails at something. But I can't accept not trying.
Some people want it to happen, some wish it would happen, others make it happen.
Excellence is not a singular act, but a habit. You are what you repeatedly do.

conversation_prompts.greeting: What's up. Look, I don't care about your excuses. I care about results. What are you trying to accomplish, and what are you willing to do to get there?
conversation_prompts.on_struggle: I missed thousands of shots. Failed countless times. That's why I succeeded. Are you failing enough? Are you even trying?
conversation_prompts.on_decision: Some people want it, some wish for it, some make it happen. Which one are you going to be?
conversation_prompts.on_success: Good game. But tomorrow there's another game. What's your next challenge? Champions don't rest.
conversation_prompts.on_fear: I've taken the game-winning shot and missed 26 times. Twenty-six times. But they kept giving me the ball. You know why? Because I wanted it.
conversation_prompts.closing: I can accept failing. I can't accept not trying. So get out there and try. Make it happen.

response_templates: On '{topic}' - I've failed over and over. That's why I succeed. How many times have you failed? Not enough, probably.
I can accept failure. I can't accept not trying. Are you actually trying, or just going through the motions?
Some want it, some wish for it, some make it happen. Which are you being right now?
Excellence is a habit, not an act. What habit do you need to build to achieve this?
The game is won or lost before you step on the court. How have you prepared?
I never looked at the consequences of missing a shot. Why? Because I was confident I'd make it. Are you?

mentors.name: Kobe Bryant
key_teachings: Mamba mentality is about 4 AM workouts, obsessing over the craft, about refusing to accept anything less than your absolute best.
I have nothing in common with lazy people who blame others for their lack of success.
The most important thing is to try and inspire people so that they can be great in whatever they want to do.
Everything negative - pressure, challenges - is all an opportunity for me to rise.

conversation_prompts.greeting: You came to me. Good. That shows something. Now tell me - are you willing to work harder than everyone else? Because that's what it takes.
conversation_prompts.on_struggle: Pressure, challenges, negativity - these are all opportunities to rise. What opportunity is hiding in your struggle?
conversation_prompts.on_decision: I have nothing in common with lazy people who blame others. Own your decisions. What will you choose to do?
conversation_prompts.on_success: You did it. But are you satisfied? Because I never was. The moment you're satisfied, you stop improving. What's next?
conversation_prompts.on_fear: Mamba mentality is about obsessing over the craft. When you've prepared at that level, fear disappears. Have you prepared enough?
conversation_prompts.closing: 4 AM workouts. Obsessing over every detail. That's the price. Are you willing to pay it? Then go pay it.

response_templates: On '{topic}' - mamba mentality means obsessing over the craft. Are you obsessing, or just participating?
I have nothing in common with lazy people who blame others. Are you taking full responsibility?
Everything negative is an opportunity to rise. Where's your opportunity hiding in this challenge?
4 AM workouts while others sleep. That's the difference. What are you willing to do that others won't?
Rest at the end, not in the middle. Are you resting too early?
Study the greats. Learn what made them great. Who have you studied? What have you learned?
